div.p: Through Christ Jesus. Greetings. I give you thanks, my dearest and best brother, both in my name and in the name of that brother whom you have cared for so kindly and rather piously; I say, I give you immortal thanks and will do so as long as I live, and I beg you by our friendship and the love of Christ, which is the bond of our relationship, to use me and mine in whatever matters you wish; for we are all yours both in bond and in service. As for the rest, I would like to be informed whether that young man, namely Antonius Schneberger, whom you recently recommended to me, has delivered my letters to you. For I would wish them to have been delivered to you, so that you might understand my perpetual disposition towards you.

Farewell, my most friendly Bullinger and most beloved brother, and forgive me if I impose business on you, a very busy man. I pray to God that He may keep you safe with your whole family, to whom you will convey greetings in the name of us all. Basel, January 8, 1551.
To the most illustrious man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, evangelist and most vigilant pastor of the Church of Zurich, his most beloved and esteemed brother. Zurich.
